Palsgraf v. Long Island R. Co., 248 N.Y..raw_text: Palsgraf v. Long Island R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928)
Palsgraf v. Long Island R. Co., 248 N.Y..proposition: - Palsgraf v. Long Island R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928) (duty and foreseeability principles)
Palsgraf v. Long Island R. Co., 248 N.Y..case_name: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R. Co., 248 N.Y..support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses duty and foreseeability as core negligence principles. Cardozo holds that duty is relational and defined by the risks reasonably foreseeable to an ordinarily prudent person, and that there is no negligence unless there is a duty owed to the particular plaintiff. This case is classic authority for using foreseeability to define the scope of duty in negligence law.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R. Co., 248 N.Y..relevant_excerpt: “The conduct of the defendant’s guard, if a wrong in its relation to the holder of the package, was not a wrong in its relation to the plaintiff, standing far away. Relatively to her it was not negligence at all… ‘In every instance, before negligence can be predicated of a given act, back of the act must be sought and found a duty to the individual complaining…’ … ‘The risk reasonably to be perceived defines the duty to be obeyed, and risk imports relation; it is risk to another or to others within the range of apprehension.’”

Mullaney v. Wilbur, 421 Mass. 1 (1995).proposition: - Mullaney v. Wilbur, 421 Mass. 1 (1995) (on causation and proximate cause in tort cases)
Mullaney v. Wilbur, 421 Mass. 1 (1995).case_name: Commonwealth v. Fourteen Thousand Two Hundred Dollars
Mullaney v. Wilbur, 421 Mass. 1 (1995).support_reasoning: The provided text is a dissent in a forfeiture/ex post facto case and focuses on whether forfeiture is punitive or remedial, the applicable burden of proof, and the admissibility of hearsay in establishing probable cause. It does not discuss causation or proximate cause doctrines in tort law, nor does it analyze causal chains, foreseeability, or related concepts. Therefore, this opinion does not support a proposition about causation and proximate cause in tort cases.
Mullaney v. Wilbur, 421 Mass. 1 (1995).relevant_excerpt: “This finding of the judge regarding the source of the money is unsupported by any credible or admissible evidence. Surely, law enforcement officers may give opinions about instrumentalities and evidence of crimes. … Here, there are no ‘basic facts’ which support the officer’s opinion regarding the source of the money.”
